metadata.synopsis: After getting canned from his advertising job, down-and-out divorcé Bill Rago (Danny DeVito) gets a gig teaching English at a nearby army base. There, he takes on a group of underachieving students from poor backgrounds who seem apathetic about their education. Bill becomes frustrated, but finally turns the class around when he begins discussing "Hamlet." However, Sgt. Cass (Gregory Hines), a hardened drill instructor, is skeptical of Bill's teaching methods.

reviews: There's a fine line between delighting an audience and pandering to it. "Renaissance Man" leapfrogs across the line.
This is a feel good movie which is too mechanically put together to make you feel anything.
In essence, a painfully earnest sit-com.
As is, highlights are too often followed by lulls of inactivity or feel-good moments that cause the narrative to drag.
Having taken basic training at Ft Jackson, SC this film had a lot of memories for me. Plus Penny Marshall autographed my "League of Their Own" poster for me after the premiere.
It enjoys its share of wisecracks, and beyond that means to be a cry for literacy and learning. But as a one-book movie, it's part of the problem rather than part of the solution.
Okay "heartwarming" drama. Tries too hard, but mostly works.

As strange as it sounds, DeVito's performance is about the only aspect of the film that isn't wholly fraudulent, if only because his typical feisty abrasiveness protects him from sinking to the level of Marshall's mawkishness.
